The Looking Glass Regional Fire Authority has participated in initial butane process and response training.  Additionally, annual notification and coordination exercises are completed with local first responders.

E. PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

MPLX is continually striving to make the Lansing LP Terminal the safest and most reliable workplace possible for its employees, neighbors and community.

In an effort to improve and promote a process safety culture, employees complete multiple PSM and RMP related education opportunities along with establishing regular terminal representative meetings and maintaining consistent communication with its butane business partner.

Additionally, Marathon employs API 754 practices to report, track, and evaluate leading and lagging indicators associated with process safety events.

serve certain safety precautions during handling to prevent unnecessary human exposure, to reduce the threat to employee health, and to minimize the threat and impact to nearby members of the community.  Safety at the Facility depends upon the manner in which butane is handled as well as the various safety systems incorporated into the design of the process. Furthermore, comprehensive training is provided to employees, which reinforces the safety policies and procedures of the Lansing LP Terminal.

The facility has fixed inventories of butane. Butane is received by truck (transports) and stored in one (1) 90,000 gal. pressure vessel.  The butane is then pumped to a blending/injection skid for direct injection into blend grade and premium unleaded gasoline lines feeding the site gasoline truck-loading rack. Injection quantities are controlled via the blending skid, analyzer and PLC. Process safety controls include internal/excess flow valves, fusible elements (<250 degrees Fahrenheit), emergency shut-off valves (fail safe), 85% fill shutoff on the vessel, manual emergency shutoff devices (ESDs) throughout and on the video display terminal, line hydrostatic pressure reliefs, and grounding/interlock devices.   Access to the Lansing LP Terminal is restricted to authorized employees, management personnel and authorized contractors/visitors.

B. GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION MEASURES

Marathon's accidental release prevention and emergency planning/response programs help effectively manage the hazards posed by the Terminal's regulated substances to its employees, the public, and the environment. The covered process is regulated by the EPA RMP regulation 40 CFR Part 68, as well as the OSHA Process Safety Management standard 29 CFR 1910.119.  The following accident prevention program elements are in place at the Lansing LP Terminal:

1) Employee Participation,
2) Process Safety Information,
3) Process Hazard Analysis (PHA),
4)

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RELEASE POLICIES

MPLX Terminals, LLC - Lansing LP Terminal is a refined petroleum product distributor. The Lansing LP Terminal is an onshore, light products, bulk petroleum storage terminal used in the storage and distribution of petroleum products to retail and commercial end-users in the vicinity of Lansing, MI. The Terminal handles and stores various grades of unleaded gasoline, low-sulfur diesel, fuel oil, butane, ethanol, and various other petroleum based additives.

The Lansing LP Terminal is committed to operating and maintaining processes in a safe, reliable and environmentally sound manner. Marathon believes that excellent performance in health, safety, and the environment (HES) goes hand in hand with operating reliably, and that outstanding HES performance is of paramount importance.

The Lansing LP Terminal is designed, operated and maintained in a manner that protects the environment, as well as the health and safety of our employees, contractors and the community. Marathon promotes health, safety, and the environment through programs of awareness, compliance, prevention and protection. These programs include a combination of accidental release prevention and emergency response planning. This document provides a brief overview of the comprehensive risk management activities that Marathon has developed and implemented, including:

A. A description of the facility and the use of regulated substances;
B. An overview of the accidental release prevention programs;
C. A five-year accident history for accidental releases of regulated chemicals;
D. An overview of the emergency response program; and
E. An overview of planned changes to improve safety.

A. STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES
